title: The Slow Erosion of Language Learning In The UK, And Why It Should Worry Us All.
content: “To have another language is to possess a second soul.” Charlemagne (742–814) As a language teacher, it pains me to witness and say this: the UK is quietly dismantling its relationship with language learning. And the consequences reach far beyond classrooms. We know - and research confirms - that learning another language strengthens cognitive development, sharpens memory, builds empathy, boosts career prospects, and deepens cultural awareness. And yet, despite all these proven benefits, languages are becoming an endangered subject in Great Britain. And not because students are uninterested or incapable, but because the system around them is quietly withdrawing its support. A SHRINKING LANDSCAPE: UNIVERISTIES CLOSING THEIR MFL DEPARTMENTS ![The Slow Erosion of Language Learning In The UK, And Why It Should Worry Us All.](https://hxzxyrlkaczsmhgf.public.blob.vercel-storage.com/blog/1765215670873-387199468-what-do-you-think-the-decline-of-modern-foreign-languages-v0-b5241sbd0o1f1-Q8J8UYu5g1yOR03z36hhCVT78JpP39.webp) The situation has become so severe that even universities, traditionally the backbone of language scholarship, are cutting entire language departments. Recently, several institutions have made headlines for suspending or planning to close Modern Foreign Languages: - University of Nottingham suspended all undergraduate MFL and music courses for new students, citing financial pressures and declining enrolment (2025). - University of Leicester launched a consultation to halt new entrants for MFL and film studies from 2026–27. - Cardiff University explored cuts to MFL, music, and nursing as part of cost-saving measures earlier in 2025. - University of Aberdeen, and before them Hull, Anglia Ruskin, Liverpool John Moores, all reduced or eliminated languages, contributing to what experts now call "linguistic deserts" across the UK. This isn’t happening in isolation. It’s the result of a long chain reaction that began years ago when the government made MFL optional at GCSE in 2004. Since then, fewer students have taken languages at GCSE, which means fewer at A level, which means fewer at university… until departments can no longer justify their existence. The “societal shift” universities cite is not organic. It’s systemic. INSIDE SCHOOLS: TOO FEW TEACHERS, YET TOO FEW OPPORTUNITIES From inside the classroom, the picture is just as troubling. As an MFL teacher myself, I have repeatedly seen language teachers asked to teach languages they don’t even speak. Not because schools are careless, but because there simply aren’t enough qualified teachers to fill the roles. And yet, paradoxically, there are almost no MFL teaching jobs advertised. How do we reconcile a teacher shortage with a vacancy shortage? Simple: schools are reducing provision because languages are no longer seen as essential. So students are given the message, explicitly or implicitly, that languages are “nice to have,” a kind of academic decoration rather than a valuable skill. Ambitious students who do want to study languages at A level are often discouraged because they’re told it’s too risky, too hard, or not useful enough. Why pursue French, Spanish, or German if the universities themselves are shutting their doors? A CULTURAL MINDSET THAT DOES NOT SUPPORT LANGUAGES In my opinion, though, one of the biggest obstacles is cultural. In the UK, many children grow up hearing the same refrain: “Why learn another language? Everyone speaks English anyway.” Parents repeat it. Students absorb it. And because the school system hasn’t invested in countering this myth, many young people genuinely don’t see the point. In many European countries like France, Italy or Spain, the media landscape itself nurtures curiosity for other languages: international music on the radio, multilingual artists on mainstream TV, exposure to foreign films and accents, and a strong awareness of Europe and the wider world. France requires radio stations to play what they call, a significant percentage of French-language music... typically around 35-40% (only!). In Scandinavian countries, for example, major movies are not dubbed, but shown in their original language with subtitles. In the UK, however, we overwhelmingly consume English-language media. When was the last time you heard a song in a language other than English on the radio? Children in multilingual families, especially in diverse cities like London, often grow up hearing more than one language, giving them an invaluable advantage. But most children in the UK only hear English at home and in the media, and schools are not counterbalancing this. With so little exposure, they don’t get to see why learning another language is important or empowering. Language learning is treated as something difficult, boring, or reserved for an academic elite, and the system reinforces this at every level. WHAT STUDENTS ARE NOT BEING TOLD ABOUT THE FUTURE Here’s the irony: we’re pushing children into STEM subjects with the promise that they’ll secure the “careers of the future,” while completely overlooking the reality that many of these fields are becoming increasingly automated. Mathematical problems? AI can already solve them. Rigid, formulaic tasks? Machines handle them effortlessly. Science and maths are wonderful, but they aren’t built on interpretation, and that is exactly where AI thrives. Language, on the other hand, deals with meaning, nuance, ambiguity, culture, humanity. It requires understanding context, emotion, intention... all things that machines struggle to truly replicate. Languages open doors to complex cultural universes, new ways of thinking, and new identities. They teach us empathy, flexibility, and perspective - skills desperately needed in an interconnected world. Yet we are quietly steering students away from them. WHAT WE GAIN WHEN WE INVEST IN LANGUAGES. Learning a language doesn’t just teach grammar and vocabulary. It teaches students: - how to understand a different worldview - how to navigate nuance - how to communicate across cultures - how to see themselves from the outside - how to think more flexibly - how to belong in a global community These are not “nice extras.” They are life skills, professional skills, human skills. And in a world where international communication is the holy grail of modern life, it is appalling that we are phasing out one of the few disciplines that explicitly trains students to communicate. A CALL TO RE-EXAMINE OUR PRIORITIES We cannot keep telling students that languages don’t matter, then wonder why our economy lacks multilingual professionals. We cannot keep closing MFL departments, then pretend to be global leaders. We cannot keep deprioritising languages in schools while expecting young people to thrive in a world that is more connected than ever before. Language learning delivers far more than translation skills. It shapes minds, expands horizons, and builds bridges. When we push it aside, we don’t just lose vocabulary. We lose curiosity. We lose cultural confidence. We lose a vital part of what makes us human. And that is the real tragedy.
